questions.text:
Which of the following vector indices are related specifically to the mosquito shown in the image?
  1. Human Blood Index
  2. Biting Density
  3. Aedes aegypti index
  4. Inoculation rate
  5. Annual parasite incidence
questions.solution:
The image given is that of an Anopheles mosquito, which is the vector for malaria. Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high as shown in the image above. 

Malarial vector indices include the following:

  1. Human Blood Index
  2. Sporozoite rate
  3. Mosquito Density
  4. Man Biting Rate
  5. Inoculation Rate
  • Human Blood Index: Proportion of freshly-fed female Anopheline mosquitoes whose stomach contains human blood. It indicates the degree of anthrophilism.
  • Sporozoite rate: Percentage of female anophelines with sporozoites in their salivary glands.
  • Mosquito Density: Number of mosquitoes per man- hour-catch.
  • Man Biting Rate (Biting density): Average incidence of anopheline bites per day per person. It is determined by standardized vector catches on human bait.
  • Inoculation Rate: The man-biting rate multiplied by the infective sporozoite rate is called the inoculation rate.

All these rates are employed in the quantitative assessment of malaria and in building up a composite epidemiological picture of malaria.

Other options:

Aedes aegypti index: This is a house index and is defined as the percentage of houses and their premises, in a limited well-defined area, showing actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae. This index should be less than 1 percent in towns and seaports in endemic areas with yellow fever.

The annual parasite incidence is used in classifying states/UTs in the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India. The annual parasite Incidence is calculated as (Cases in one year ×1000) / Population under surveillance. It is a measure of malaria incidence.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A young male was managed with the following cast for a closed fracture of the leg, which was associated with few abrasions over the ankle. According to biomedical waste management, this cast should be disposed of in which of the following bins?
questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management, used plaster casts, contaminated with body fluids, should be disposed of in a yellow colored bag. All the soiled waste items like dressings, cotton swabs and plaster casts are discarded in the yellow bin.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

Microbiology, biotechnology, clinical laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, laboratory
cultures, stocks or specimens of microorganisms,
live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/plasma pyrolysis/ disposal in a secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Encapsulation- hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility.

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: An elderly man was caught peeping into a bathroom window and watching a girl disrobe. During the psychiatric evaluation, he confessed that he attains sexual gratification when he watches people naked or while they are engaged in any sexual activity without their knowledge. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Attaining sexual gratification after observing someone naked or engaged in sexual activity is called voyeurism. 

Voyeurism is also called scopophilia. It is more common in men. The voyeuristic act may be accompanied by masturbation. 

Paraphilias (perversions) are sexual stimuli or acts that are considered deviations from normal sexual behaviors. These are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm. Individuals with paraphilias do not experience sexual pleasure through stimuli that are considered normal.

Other options:

Option A: In transvestism there is a sexual urge to dress in opposite gender clothing as a means of arousal. It is diagnosed when these fantasies have been acted upon for at least six months. 

Option B: Coprophilia is attaining sexual pleasure by defecating on the partner or by being defecated on. An urge to eat feces (coprophagia) may also be seen. 

Option D: Frotteurism is characterized by the rubbing of genitals against the buttocks or any other parts of the body of a woman who is fully clothed. This is done to achieve an orgasm and usually occurs in crowded places.

Note: Exhibitionism is characterized by a recurrent urge to expose the genitals to strangers. The anticipation of the exposure results in sexual excitement and orgasm.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: A 32-year-old male smoker presents with intermittent claudication and gangrene of the lower extremities. Biopsy of the blood vessels supplying this area shows acute and chronic inflammation, with luminal thrombosis containing small neutrophilic microabscesses. Granulomatous inflammation appears to extend into the contiguous veins and nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease.

It is the segmental, thrombosing, acute and chronic inflammation of medium-sized and small arteries. It principally involves the tibial and radial arteries.

It is seen in heavy cigarette smokers, usually before the age of 35 years. HLA-A-9 and HLA-B-5 associated with a high risk of TAO.

The patients present with intermittent claudication, chronic ulcerations of the extremity, and later progress to frank gangrene. The microscopy findings include luminal thrombosis (thrombangiitis), that is, thrombus containing microabscesses that occlude the lumen (obliterans). They contain small microabscesses composed of neutrophils.

Berger disease refers to IgA nephropathy. It is seen within 3-5 days of sore throat. It is associated with purpuric rash in the lower limbs.

questions.text:
A girl presented with itching and oozing from a lesion on the ear after wearing nickel earrings. Identify the correct statements about the test used to confirm the diagnosis.
  1. Based on delayed hypersensitivity reaction
  2. Eczematous disorders unresponsive to treatment is an indication
  3. Testing should be delayed for 4 weeks following sunbathing
  4. Low-dose steroids hamper the positive response and are a contraindication for the test
  5. The optimum site for the test is the abdomen
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above is suggestive of allergic contact dermatitis to nickel. The test used to confirm the diagnosis is the patch test and statements 1,2 and 3 are the correct statements regarding it. 

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity (Statement 1) to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning). The patch site is evaluated 1 hour after removal, on day 2, and on day 4 to detect delayed reactions.

Site- Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm. The abdomen and thigh are less suitable sites, that are very rarely used.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment (Statement 2)
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing (Statement 3), and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may result in false negatives in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg of prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected. 

The image below shows the patch test.

questions.text:
The line joining the points O, N and F is called ______.
(Where, O is the fixation point, N is the center of the lens, F is the Fovea, R is the center of the retina and P is the center of the cornea)
questions.solution:
Visual axis is the line joining the fixation point(O), nodal point/the center of the lens (N), and the fovea (F).

OTHER AXIS OF EYE

  • Optical axis:

                      The line passing through the center of the cornea (P), the center of the lens (N) and meets the retina (R) on the nasal side of the fovea.

                      It is also referred to as Principal axis

  • Fixation axis:

                      The line joining the fixation point (O) and the center of rotation (C).

VISUAL ANGLES

  • Angle alpha. It is the angle (ONA) formed between the optical axis (AR) and visual axis (OF) at the nodal point (N).
  • Angle gamma. It is the angle (OCA) between the optical axis (AR) and fixation axis (OC) at the center of rotation of the eyeball (C).
  • Angle kappa. It is the angle (OPA) formed between the visual axis (OF) and pupillary line (AP).

Note:

  • A positive angle kappa results in pseudo-exotropia
  • A negative angle kappa results in  pseudo-esotropia

Related Pearl: Axes of the Eye

Axes of the eye: 

Axis  Description
Optic Axis  Line passing through the center of the cornea and centre of the lens to meet the retina on the nasal side of the fovea.
Visual Axis   Line joining the fixation point (object), nodal point (centre of the lens), and the fovea
Fixation Axis   Line joining the fixation point (object) and the centre of rotation

Angles of the eye: 

  Visual axis Line of sight Fixation axis
Pupillary axis Kappa (κ) Lambda (λ)  
Optic Axis Alpha (α)   Gamma (γ)

questions.text:
Match the following options with the respective skull fractures shown in the given image.

Image A

Image B

Image C

Image D

  1. Gutter fracture
  2. Pond's fracture
  3. Mosaic fracture
  4. Fissured fracture
questions.solution:
A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Pond fracture occurs in children due to the elasticity of bones. It is also known as an indented fracture.

Fissured fractures of the skull are linear skull fractures without any displacement of the fragments.

Gutter fracture of the skull is a furrow in the outer table of the skull, ordinarily the result of a glancing blow by a missile from a rifled firearm. These are frequently accompanied with comminuted depressed fractures of the inner table of the skull.

Mosaic Fracture (Spider's Web Fracture) of the skull is a comminuted depressed fracture that also has fissures radiating from it, forming a spider’s-web or mosaic pattern.

 

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old comes with a painless ulcerative lesion on her vulva. On observing a culture specimen processed using the Levaditi staining method, the following appearance is seen. Which of the following are appropriate treatment regimens that can be used for treating the underlying disease?
  1. Amoxycillin 500mg qid x 14 days
  2. Doxycycline 100mg bd x 14 days
  3. 1.2 million units benzathine penicillin IM
  4. Erythromycin 500mg bd x 14 days
  5. Azithromycin 500mg od x 10 days
questions.solution:
The slide shows a culture specimen stained with the Levaditi stain showing the presence of corkscrew-shaped organisms which is indicative of a Treponema pallidum infection causing syphilis. For patients with syphilis, Amoxycillin 500mg qid x 14 days, Doxycycline 100mg bd x 14 days, Azithromycin 500mg od x 10 days are appropriate treatment regimens that can be used.

2.4 (not 1.2) million units benzathine penicillin IM is considered to be the drug of choice and alternative regimens are used in those with penicillin allergy. Erythromycin 500mg qid(not BD) x 14 days can also be used for treating this.

 

Treatment of Syphilis - 

  • Screening for other STDs and HIV.
  • Counselling about high-risk behaviour
  • Counselling for treatment expected course of the disease, risk of fetal transmission and its sequelae if untreated
  • Treating all sexual partners of an infected individual.
  • Specific treatment:
    • 2.4 million units of benzathine penicillin are given IM. In latent disease of >1year duration, penicillin is repeated weekly for 3 weeks.
    • Doxycycline 100 mg bd for 14 days.
    • Erythromycin 500 mg qid for 14 days.
    • Azithromycin 500 mg od for 10 days.
    • Amoxycillin 500 mg qid for 14 days
  • Follow-up serology titres should show a decrease of 4 fold after 3–6 months.
  • Recommend barrier contraceptives to prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about the deterministic effects of radiation.
  1. It is associated with damage to the DNA of cells.
  2. The severity of these effects is independent of the dose received.
  3. Examples include oligospermia, skin erythema, and epilation.
  4. Below the threshold dose, harmful effects do not occur.
  5. The fetus is more vulnerable to these effects between the 2nd to 20th week of gestation
questions.solution:
Statements 3, 4, and 5 are correct about the deterministic effects of radiation.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: Stochastic effects and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects: 

These effects do not occur below a threshold dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. These effects are associated with radiation-induced killing or malfunction of cells. Skin erythema, epilation, cataracts, and transient oligospermia are a few examples of nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

The fetus is most vulnerable to deterministic effects of radiation between the 2nd and 20th week of gestation. Usually, no deterministic effects occur at a dose below 100 mGy which is the threshold for most imaging modalities.

Stochastic effects: 

Stochastic effects of ionizing radiation are chance events associated with damage to the DNA of cells. They may result in cancer or heritable effects. The incidence of these effects is directly proportionate to the dose of radiation in organs or tissues, but the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. (All or none phenomenon)

questions.text: A professor demonstrates the following reflex on a healthy child. He tests you by listing out the abnormal responses of this reflex and the conditions where those are seen. Which among them is wrongly paired?
questions.solution:
The reflex shown in the image is the Moro reflex. Kernicterus is associated with a loss of Moro reflex, not an exaggerated Moro reflex.

The above-animated gif shows a normal response to Moro's reflex where there are symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by anterior flexion of the upper extremities, associated with an audible cry.

 The Moro reflex:

  • It is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness.
  • The Moro reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age in normal infants. 
  • It can be elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backward onto the examiner’s hand.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: Feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly vera

 

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

 
Reflex
Onset
Fully developed 
Duration
Palmar grasp
28 weeks of gestation
32 weeks of gestation
2-3 months postnatal
Rooting
32 weeks of gestation
36 weeks of gestation
Less prominent after 1 month postnatal
Moro
28-32 weeks of gestation
37 weeks of gestation
5-6 months postnatal
Tonic neck
35 weeks of gestation
1 month postnatal
3-4 months postnatal
Parachute
7-8 months postnatal
10-11 months postnatal
Remains throughout life

 

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes pancreatic necrosectomy. The surgeon decides to place abdominal drains following the procedure. Which of the given suture materials is preferred for securing the drain externally?
questions.solution:
Silk sutures are commonly used to secure external drains.

Silk is a blue/black-colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks, and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It can be used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It can also be used for skin closure; however, there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. 


Other options:

Option A: Polydioxanone is a delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option B: Monocryl (Polygylcaprone) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Option D: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is one of the best sutures for vascular anastomosis.  It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

Related Pearl: Suture materials

Suture Types Uses

Absorbable suture materials
Catgut Plain/Chromic

Ligate superficial vessels

Suture subcutaneous tissues, stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly
Polyglactin (Vicryl) Braided multifilament

Gut and biliary anastomoses

Vascular ligatures

Kidney and ureter surgeries.

Subcuticular wound

Polydioxanone

Monofilament

Dyed or undyed

Used in tissues where slightly longer wound support is required

Poliglecaprone (Monocryl)

 Monofilament

Subcuticular suturing of skin

Soft tissue ligation

Gastrointestinal and muscle surgery
Non-absorbable suture materials
Silk

Braided or twisted multifilament

Coated (with wax or silicon) or uncoated

Ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary

For securing drains externally, two-layer bowel anastomoses

Surgical steel

Monofilament or multifilament

Closure of sternotomy wounds
Nylon

Monofilament or braided multifilament

Skin closure

Abdominal wall closure

Hernia repair

Neurosurgery

Polybutester

Monofilament

Exhibits elasticity. Favoured for use in plastic surgery
 

Polypropylene (Prolene)

 Monofilament   

Cardiovascular surgery and vascular anastomosis 

Plastic surgery

General surgical subcuticular skin closure

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with hip pain after a fall. X-ray reveals a fracture of the neck of her femur. Which of the following instruments is best suited for cutting bone while performing McMurray's osteotomy for her condition?
questions.solution:
Among the instruments given, image C represents an osteotome that can be used to cut bone while performing an osteotomy.

Osteotome-

An osteotome has both sides beveled. It is used for cutting bone.

Ex:

  • McMurray's osteotomy for fracture of neck of femur. 
  • Corrective osteotomy for genu varum and genu valgum. 

Other options:

Image A is the periosteal elevator. It is used to elevate the periosteum as nerves, and vessels are generally on this plane, and once this has been elevated the surgeon is on a safer plane.

Image B is a curette used for curetting a cavity in bone or removing fibrous tissue from ends of fracture; used in enchondroma, GCT, osteomyelitis.

Image D is bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting on round bone surfaces or making round holes in bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: N2O is not a suitable agent for use all of the following patients except:

choices.text: A 42 year old RTA victim who is found to have pneumocephalus on CT scan
A 27 year old female with a low pain tolerance who is very anxious about the dental procedure she is set to undergo
A 31 year old female who is set to undergo a tympanoplasty
A 39 year old male with acute intestinal obstruction and bowel distension

questions.solution:
A 27-year-old female with a low pain tolerance who is very anxious about the dental procedure she is set to undergo would be a suitable candidate for use of N2O

Cases in which nitrous oxide is contraindicated: 

  • venous or arterial air embolism
  • pneumothorax,
  • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention,
  • intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography),
  • pulmonary air cysts,
  • intraocular air bubbles,
  • tympanic membrane grafting

Nitrous oxide is an inhalational anaesthetic agent that is used predominantly as an adjuvant during inhalational induction of general anaesthesia. 

Typical clinical uses include:

Induction - It is used as an adjuvant because of the low solubility in blood. Due to this, the rate of rise of alveolar concentration (low blood:gas partition coefficient) occurs very rapidly which makes it suitable for this purpose. It has a low potency (MAC value of 104) which makes in unsuitable for use as a sole anaesthetic agent

Maintenance - It can be used for maintenance of anaesthesia because it is cost-effective and the dose of other drugs used in combination can be lowered appropriately

Sedation - It may be used for short procedures'

 Advantages of N20:

  • It is a sweet-smelling gas that is not pungent and does not cause airway irritation
  • Very low blood: gas partition coefficient
  • Increased speed of anaesthetic onset and offset when used in combination with other agents which is called the second-gas effect
  • Analgesic and anxiolytic properties makes it ideal for induction
  • No major effects on haemodynamics
  • Low cost 

Adverse effects and disadvantages:

  • Very low potency
  • Ability to diffuse into air-filled cavities to displace nitrogen
  • Transient diffusion hypoxia  at low inspired oxygen concentrations
  • Myocardial depression, sympathetic nervous system stimulation and mildly increased pulmonary vascular resistance.
  • Inactivation of Vitamin B12 which leads to inhibition of methionine synthetase activity

 

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: A laboratory technician measures the renal plasma flow of a patient using para amino hippuric acid clearance. The procedure was completed and the patient was sent back to the ward. After the senior technician arrived it was found that the dose of para amino hippuric acid used was thrice the recommended dose, but the rest of the process was carried out correctly. The renal plasma flow estimated due to this error is likely to be

choices.text: Can be falsely high or low

questions.solution:
Administration of very high doses of para-amino hippuric acid will result in an estimation of falsely low renal plasma flow.

Use of para-amino hippuric acid (PAH) in the estimation of renal plasma flow (RPF)

The renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time. By this definition, it is evident that if a substance is completely cleared from the plasma in a unit of time, then the clearance of the substance will be equal to that of renal plasma flow. Eg. para-amino hippuric acid. It is around 90% cleared from the kidneys. Therefore it is used in the calculation of RPF.

Therefore, RPF will be equal to the clearance of PAH (CPAH) which is given by the formula,

CPAH= (UPAH X V)/PPAH 

Where PPAH is the plasma concentration of the PAH, UPAH is the urine concentration of PAH, and V is the urine flow rate.

By this, we can understand that it is directly proportional to the urinary concentration of PAH and inversely proportional to the plasma concentration. The substances which are secreted have a transport maximum which is the maximum limit of the rate of secretion. Once this is achieved, the urinary concentration of the solute will remain constant. Therefore, when higher doses of PAH are administered, the plasma concentration rises, but the urine concentration will remain constant. This will lead to a falsely low estimation of RPF.

Related Pearl: Formulae in renal physiology

Term

Equation

Clearance rate

Us ×V / Ps

 

Glomerular filtration rate

Uinulin × V / Pinulin

 

Clearance ratio

Cs/Cinulin

Effective renal plasma flow

ERPF=CPAH=UPAH ×V / PPAH

 

 

Renal blood flow

RPF / (1− Hematocrit)

Excretion rate

Us ×V

 

Reabsorption rate

=Filtered load −Excretion rate

=(GFR×Ps)−(Us ×V)

Secretion rate

Excretion rate−Filtered load

Cs - clearance rate of substance “s”

EPAH  - PAH extraction ratio

ERPF - effective renal plasma flow

GFR - glomerular filtration rate

P - plasma concentration

PAH - para-aminohippuric acid

PPAH - renal arterial PAH concentration

RBF - renal blood flow

RPF - renal plasma flow

S - a substance

U - urine concentration

V - urine flow rate

VPAH - renal venous PAH concentration

questions.text:
Which of these sites have tanycytes and lack blood-brain barrier?
  1. Area postrema
  2. The suprafornical organ
  3. The supracommissural organ
  4. Organum vasculosum
  5. The anterior pituitary
questions.solution:
Area postrema and Organum vasculosum are circumventricular organs that have tanycytes and lack blood-brain barrier.

Tanycytes are specialized ependymal cells present in circumventricular organs. The functions of these ependymas and tanycytes include secretion of substances into the CSF, chemoreception, transport of neurochemicals from adjacent neurons, glial cells, or vessels to the CSF, and transport of neurochemicals from the CSF to the same adjacent structures.

The anterior pituitary has a normal blood-brain barrier. It is the posterior pituitary that lacks the blood-brain barrier.

Circumventricular organs (CVOs) are midline structures in the ventricular wall and are characterized by their extensive vasculature and lack of a normal blood-brain barrier (BBB). They are:

  • Area postrema
  • The subfornical organ
  • The subcommissural organ
  • Vascular organ of lamina terminalis (organum vasculosum)
  • The posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis)
  • The pineal gland
  • The median eminence

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for anemia. The oral and eye examination findings are shown below. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with its image showing cheilosis, angular stomatitis, a magenta-colored tongue, and corneal vascularisation, points to the diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency. RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing this condition.

Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products.

The following signs and symptoms characterize the deficiency state of riboflavin:

  • Cheilosis- pallor in the angle of the mouth and fissuring of the lips, which extends radially to the skin.
  • Glossitis- the tongue becomes smooth, and there is a loss of papillae (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes- keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features- seborrheic dermatitis and anemia.

Note: Because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Other options:

Option A: RBC transketolase assay diagnoses vitamin B1/ thiamine deficiency. Thiamine deficiency mainly manifests as peripheral neuritis, beriberi, and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option B: The serum methyl malonate level is used to diagnose vitamin B12/ methylcobalamin deficiency. Patients typically present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and signs and symptoms of subacute combined degeneration, manifesting as loss of vibration and proprioception and absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option C: The RBC transaminase assay assesses glutamate levels inside RBCs. Human erythrocytes require a continual supply of glutamate to support glutathione synthesis, but this is not routinely tested.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

questions.text: A young patient presents with a persistent and painful penile erection. He had been taking sildenafil without proper medical consultation. Which of the following drugs can be given as an intracavernosal injection to this patient?
questions.solution:
Intracavernous injection of phenylephrine can be given to this patient to relieve the priapism and prevent ischemic damage.

Priapism (sustained painful penile erection >4 hours) is a common and serious side effect of sildenafil. Other causes of priapism include trazodone (serotonin receptor antagonist) and cantharidin from Spanish fly.

Phenylephrine is an α1 selective adrenergic agonist. It serves as a vasoconstrictor of the arterioles and reduces the engorgement of cavernosal space, thus reversing priapism.

Phenylephrine is a pure α1 adrenergic agonist. By means of acting on α1 receptors, it increases the peripheral arterial resistance, and decreases the capacity of venous capacitance vessels, leading to an increased venous return to the heart. There is a baroreceptor reflex-mediated increase in vagal tone due to which there is marked bradycardia. However, due to increased venous return, stroke volume remains high and so does the cardiac output.

Other options:

Option B: Oxymetazoline is a vasoconstrictor used in nasal congestion and sinus surgeries. It is available generally as a nasal spray.

Options C and D: Papaverine (with or without phentolamine) and alprostadil are used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

Asthma, COPD
 

Pentoxifylline

Peripheral artery disease  
PDE 2 inhibitor

Anagrelide

 Essential thrombocytosis
PDE 3 inhibitor

Cilostazol

 Peripheral artery disease
 

Milrinone, Amrinone

PDE 4 inhibitor

Roflumilast

 COPD
 

Drotaverine

 Antispasmodic drug
PDE 5 inhibitor

Sildenafil, Vardenafil, Tadalafil (Also inhibit PDE6)

 Erectile dysfunction Pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years. 

Other options: 

Option A - Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition of the larynx that manifests at birth and disappears by the age of 2 years. Babies present with stridor on crying that relieves in the prone position. 

The following image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis of laryngomalacia:

 

Option B - Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

 

Option C - Vocal cord nodules occur at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. This occurs due to vocal trauma that happens when the patient speaks in low tones or high intensities for prolonged periods. 

The following image shows a unilateral vocal nodule:

questions.text: Thirty minutes after a blood transfusion is started, a patient develops chills and severe flank pain. Her temperature is 102.4 F, SpO2 is 96%, and her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. She then begins bleeding around her IV catheter site. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR). 

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with pain over the lateral aspect of her right breast for the past 5 days. Examination finding is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein. Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast. It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Option A: Tietze’s syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska disease is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Option D: Stewart–Treves Syndrome is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.
